p: This virus can infect children despite the presence of maternal antibodies; natural infection offers only partial protection [21]. RSV type B was found to be the most common in our study; some publications have shown that group A was associated with more severe forms of bronchiolitis, which is not the case here. RSV was identified in 3-month-old infants in an average of 84.2% of cases; average age was under 6 months. Children infected with RSV are younger than those not infected with RSV at 3.1 months versus 5.9 months. Young age is identified as the main risk factor for severe bronchiolitis [22]. Acute viral bronchiolitis does not spare newborns [23].
